prompt: List the layers of the TCP/IP model and for each layer identify one protocol.
answer:
The TCP/IP model consists of layers, each performing a set of related functions. The layers are named based on the function they perform. The most important layers of the OSI model are:

Application layer - the top layer of the model, includes protocols that define how applications communicate with each other. For example, the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) defines how email messages are sent between servers and clients.
Presentation layer - converts the information from one format to another without changing the meaning of the data. For example, the HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is a presentation layer protocol for transmitting and receiving hypertext documents, such as web pages, and the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) is a presentation layer protocol for transferring files over a network.
Session layer - focuses on managing communication sessions between two endpoints. For example, the Transport Control Protocol (TCP) and the User Datagram Protocol (UDP) are transport layer protocols for reliable and unreliable transport of information.
Transport layer - provides end-to-end connection services to transfer data between the source and destination hosts. The Internet Protocol (IP) and its successor, IPv6, are the main protocols of this layer.
Network layer - divides the network into smaller sections or routes and determines the best path for data to be sent from source to destination. The Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) are the main protocols of this layer.
Link layer - interfaces between two devices at the same network segment. For example, Ethernet and Wi-Fi are the main protocols of this layer.

Please proofread and polish the passage from an academic angle and highlight the modification:
The purpose of this research was to detect the changes of happiness, the ultimate pursuit of human being, in China, by examing happines inside Chinese brain (i.e., lay beleifs) and outside Chinese brain (i.e., natural languages). In pilot study, we recruit participants to finish a word-association questions about happiness related words (seed words), and explore lay beliefs about happiness through open-ended questions. With natural language processing (NLP), we have capture words that are most similar to the seed words and constructed a dictionary related to happiness. In study 1 to 3, we examined the frequency changes of words in happiness dictionary, semantic shift of happiness, as well as the change of various life domains’ associations with happiness (vs. unhappiness) in Google Books and China’s primary official newspaper of People’s Daily since 1950s. Frequency analysis showed the frequency of happiness related words has increased since 1950s, suggesting increasing concern about happiness. Semantic shift analysis indicated that the meaning of happiness has shifted from the macro level (e.g., collective events) to the micro level (e.g., individual experiences). Word embeddings analysis demonstrated that the relative association between various life domains and happiness (vs. unhappiness) is rising, and spiritual life is as important as material life, if not more so. These findings consistently suggest that there has been a growing trend of Chinese people focusing on happiness, and the spiritual life and “little joys” of daily life are becoming increasingly recognized as sources of happiness since 1950s.

prompt: Why can't bank use cash as capital as a buffer for potential losses?
answer:
Bank must hold some capital to protect depositors against unexpected losses. Bank earns its income by lending money to borrowers. If the borrowers default or are unable to pay back the loans, bank will suffer losses. When bank lends money, it does not get cash immediately, but receives a promise from borrowers to pay back with interest at a later date. 
Hence, bank's assets are made up of loans and other investments. If banks hold too much cash, it will not be able to earn a return on that cash. 
Banks face a "loanable funds" problem: borrowers wish to borrow at a lower interest rate than they can lend at. So banks have to find a source of funds to lend out. Banks usually borrow money in the interbank market in the form of deposits from other banks. 
Because banks borrow money at a low rate and lend it at a higher rate, they can earn a spread between what they pay and what they receive. However, the spread is not large enough to cover the risk that some of their borrowers may default. 

If bank holds too much cash, it will not earn any return on that cash. This will reduce its profitability. Hence, banks must hold some cash to meet unexpected withdrawals from depositors and to meet other short-term cash needs. 

Furthermore, banks are also required to hold a certain amount of capital to act as a buffer against losses. If the bank's assets decline in value, the bank's capital may not be sufficient to cover those losses. 

Therefore, banks are not allowed to use cash as capital as a buffer for potential losses because cash does not generate any income for the bank.

Nuclear physics studies how the nucleus is composed of protons and neutrons, and the forces that bind them together. Nuclear physicists study the properties of individual atoms, the interactions between atoms, and the structure of molecules. Nuclear physics is related to other areas of physics and chemistry, including particle physics, atomic physics, and quantum chemistry.

prompt: I'm currently studying Bioengineering in Argentina, focusing on computational neuroscience. I'll be graduating in May, and planning to apply to PhD programs in the US at the end of the year in order to start August 2024. I'm thinking of what to do/study during this year until my program starts. Could you give me ideas? Feel free to ask me for questions which would help you give me better suggestions.
answer:
I have 2 suggestions:

1) You could apply to masters programs in the US and start by the fall of 2024. They are usually 1 or 2 years long. If you get in, you could get some more training in the specific topic you'd like to do your PhD in. As well, it might give you a better chance of getting into a good PhD program. I know some people who have done this and it worked well for them.
2) You could also do a research internship in the US. It could be with a professor somewhere, or maybe at a research institute. I think this would give you a good chance to learn more about a topic you might want to do a PhD in, and could potentially get you in touch with professors who might be interested in taking you on as a PhD student.

prompt:
Why is it that only proteins, carbohydrates and fats are deemed to have caloric value?
Just to clarify - consider the hypothetical situation below:
100g of 'carbohydrates' = 400kCal
100g of 'protein' = 400kCal
100g of 'fat' = 900kCal
100g of 'vitamins, minerals and/or other electrolytes' = ?
answer: The reason that 'carbohydrates', 'protein' and 'fat' are deemed to have caloric value is because these compounds can be metabolised by the body to produce energy. 'Vitamins, minerals and/or other electrolytes', however, are not metabolised by the body for the production of energy. Instead, they play a vital role in the normal functioning of the body, such as in the regulation of body temperature or in the formation of red blood cells.

prompt:
How well does the following response respond to the prompt? ..... Prompt=  

After reading Lalor’s Chapter 8 as well as Goode’s explanation of curriculum evaluation necessity and models, explain what your school does to evaluate curriculum. Does your school utilize one of the models mentioned in Goode’s article?  (Tyler, Haba, Stake, Chronbach, CIPP) If not,how specifically does your school evaluate curriculum?  Is it effective?  Why or why not? 

Response=  

In Thornton Township district 205 the curriculum evaluation is mostly driven by the teachers and evaluated yearly over the course of the summer with “summer content institutes” in teams that consist of content area teachers and administrators. The team works together to review the textbook resource and teacher created resources to ensure alignment to content goals and Common Core standards. The method of curriculum evaluation used by Thornton district 205 mostly resembles the “Tabba Model” (Goode, 2019).   

I would say that this method is effective in theory however in practice not so much. Many teachers do not use the resources the teams create over the summers except the teachers on the team. There needs to be consistent use of the materials and unit plans to create a true gauge of effectiveness. To improve upon this, we would need curriculum teams consistently using the common unit structures and assessments and tracking of the data. With consistent data analysis, the curriculum's effectiveness can be determined and the decisions informed.  

 

 

Works Cited 

Goode, Kristen.  Curriculum Evaluation: Process and Models.  Study.com.  Retrieved October 12, 2019.
answer:
How well does the following response respond to the prompt?The following responses are based on my work experience as a science teacher and coordinator at the secondary level.

The curriculum evaluation process at the secondary level varies significantly from district to district. In the district where I was employed, the first step in the evaluation process was the selection of a content area team. This team would include the department chair, who is responsible for selecting the team members, and teachers from each grade level. The team would work together to review the textbook resource and teacher created resources to assess alignment of the materials to the district standards. The team would also review data from district and state assessments to determine the effectiveness of the curriculum. The team would then present their findings to the department chair. Depending on the feedback, the department chair would either approve the curriculum or request revisions to be made.

While the curriculum evaluation process is effective in theory, the process becomes more challenging in practice. The main issues that arise relate to the amount of time required to complete the evaluation process. The team members need to devote a significant amount of time to reviewing the materials and preparing the presentation for the department chair. In addition, there is often a lot of debate among the members of the team about the effectiveness of the materials. This debate often leads to heated discussions that can be difficult to manage.

prompt: Write me a 2000 word essay on a water safety engineering project.
answer:
A water safety engineering project involves identifying, understanding, and mitigating hazards associated with water-related activities. The project I chose to describe involves the use of a high-speed boat to navigate the Thames River in London, England.

The Thames River is tidal and wind-dominated. The river is shallow in places and has numerous obstacles and hazards; including: fixed and floating bridges, other boats, barges, and piers.

The river is also polluted by urban runoff, sewage from combined sewer overflows, and industry. The Thames is also home to a number of wildlife species, including: large fish, water birds, and marine mammals.

The project involves identifying hazards associated with operating a boat on the Thames, and designing a safe and enjoyable journey. Some of the hazards identified include: shallow water, other boats, barges, and piers, wind, weather, and tides, and wildlife.

To mitigate the hazards, the project involves navigating the river with a licensed captain, following the proper navigational rules and regulations, and keeping a safe distance from other vessels and structures.

Some of the other considerations include: planning the route and timing the trip to avoid rush hour traffic, planning the route to avoid areas with heavy commercial traffic, and planning the trip for favorable weather and tide conditions.

The project also involves being aware of the hazards associated with boating in unfamiliar tidal waters, and taking appropriate safety precautions.

prompt: How to improve instance segmentation AP metrics with human knowledge
answer:
Segmentation AP is a metric that measures the accuracy of instance-level segmentation. It is calculated as the number of correctly labeled pixels divided by the total number of pixels in the input image. 

The key to improving segmentation AP is to use human knowledge to guide the model learning. The more labeled data we provide for the model, the better it learns and the higher the segmentation AP score. However, the amount of available labeled data is usually limited. In real-world applications, we often have a small amount of labeled data to train our model. It is often not enough to achieve state-of-the-art performance.

Human knowledge is able to guide the model learning by providing the model with the understanding of what we want to segment. For example, human knows that the hair of a person is usually darker than the skin, so we can provide the model with these kinds of information to help the model learn better.

prompt: what is needed for self-sufficient living spaces
answer:
A self-sufficient living space refers to a place that is completely independent and does not need to be connected to any other space or system for its survival. Such spaces have their own sources of water, electricity, and food. A self-sufficient living space can be a house, an office, or even a vehicle. In general, a self-sufficient living space should have these basic necessities:

- Sources of water, such as a well or a rainwater collector
- Sources of electricity, such as solar panels
- Sources of food, such as a garden
- Adequate storage space for water, electricity, and food

prompt: Expand on the relation between inconsistency and ideological thinking
answer:
Consistency and ideological thinking are closely related. People often apply ideological thinking in two contexts: in the context of their own personal identity, and in the context of a group identity. In the first context, a person can be consistent with respect to their own beliefs and values, and inconsistent with respect to the beliefs and values of others. In the second context, a person can be consistent with respect to the beliefs and values of the group to which they belong, but inconsistent with respect to beliefs and values of groups to which they do not belong.

Both forms of inconsistency can be dangerous. The danger of inconsistency with respect to personal identity is that one can develop a set of beliefs and values that are coherent with one's own view of the world, but that are ultimately incompatible with reality. The danger of inconsistency with respect to group identity is that a person can be so caught up in the values and beliefs of the group to which they belong, that they are unable to recognize the flaws in those beliefs and values, and thus become a "useful idiot" for the group.

prompt: Hi, I have a question about MFCC (mel frequency cepstral coefficients). Are they the same thing as a MEL-spectogram, or is there a difference?
answer:
MFCC is an acronym for Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients. It is a feature commonly used in speech recognition and audio classification. MFCCs are computed from a short clip (usually 10 ms) of an audio signal and are typically described as a 1-dimensional vector of 39 values.

Each coefficient is calculated as the sum of the products of the short-time Fourier transform (STFT) of the mel-frequency filtered spectrogram and the corresponding mel-frequency (i.e. a frequency weighted version of the mel-frequency). 
Each frame of the STFT is then transformed to a frequency domain using the Discrete Fourier Transform. Coefficients 0 to 13 represent low frequencies, coefficients 14 to 25 medium frequencies, and coefficients 26 to 39 high frequencies.

Mill vs Gartner
This case is about a dispute over the right to dig clay on a piece of land. The plaintiffs argued that the defendant, Allen, had only a verbal agreement, or a "parol license," to enter the land and take clay. The defendant claimed that he had an actual leasehold interest in the land, which entitled him to dig clay. The court found that the defendant's defense was sufficient, as it constituted a lease of the land for the purpose of taking clay. The court also found that the defendant's offer of testimony was admissible, and that the testimony was sufficient to submit to the jury. The court concluded that the trial judge had properly ruled on the case and that the judgment should be affirmed.

Smith vs Mill Company
The case is about the interpretation of a clause in a lease agreement between the lessors and lessees regarding the payment of taxes on coal in the ground. The clause in question stated that the lessors must pay all taxes imposed on the coal in the ground. The court held that the meaning of the clause was clear and plain, and that it was an absolute obligation on the part of the lessors to pay the taxes. The court also considered the effect of deeds of conveyance made after the lease agreement and concluded that they did not change the rights of the parties under the lease agreement. The court further held that the lessees still had the exclusive privilege to take the coal and were subject to the same duties as under the lease agreement, and the lessors still held all the beneficial interests that they held under the lease agreement. The court concluded that the positive agreement of the lessors to pay the taxes was not dependent on any technical aspect of their interest in the coal and was absolute, peremptory, and without condition.

The case of "Opinion, Min Justice Mitchell" was an ejectment lawsuit brought by plaintiffs against defendants who claimed to hold possession of the plaintiffs' land as lessees. The case revolved around a lease agreement made in 1864 between the plaintiffs (who were minors at the time and represented by their guardians) and the defendants, who were lessees of the land. The lease was made with the approval of a special act of assembly. The defendants claimed that the title was res adjudicata and the judge at the trial agreed, except for the continuance of the lease beyond twenty years, which he held to still be in force as a matter of law. The remaining specifications of error raised four questions, including the constitutionality of the act of assembly, the execution of the lease in accordance with the act, the validity of the lease, and whether it had expired by its own terms. These questions were resolved in favor of the defendants and the decree was affirmed by the court in a brief per curiam opinion, referring to the absence of fraud.

prompt: In this math problem, we are asked to figure out the percentage of total profits that are made in each quarter. They are 90% in the first quarter, 92% in the second quarter, 81% in the third quarter and 88% in the fourth quarter. What is the total profit percent over a period of time, based upon these quarters?
answer: The total profit over a period of time is calculated by multiplying the percentage for each quarter by the total profits for each quarter. The total profits for each quarter are 90% of 100, 92% of 100, 81% of 100 and 88% of 100. The total profit for the different quarters are 90% x 100 = 90, 92% x 100 = 92, 81% x 100 = 81 and 88% x 100 = 88. The total profit is the sum of all the different quarters, which is 90 + 92 + 81 + 88 = 361%.

prompt: How can anti-deressants make people think or act suicidally? Suicidal thoughts or actions' are a side effect of every single anti-depressant I've seen. Is the medicine controlling your mind or something?
answer:
Anti-depressants have been found to have many side effects, including suicidal thoughts and actions.  While we don't understand the exact cause of this side effect, it has been found to be a side effect of some anti-depressants.  Suicidal thoughts or actions are not a normal side effect of any other type of medication.  It is not known if anti-depressants are causing people to have suicidal thoughts or actions, or if there is another cause for this side effect.  It is also not known if anti-depressants are controlling your mind or something.  It is possible that, after taking anti-depressants for a long time, you may have a hard time functioning without them.  This is called withdrawal, and can be very uncomfortable.  It is also possible that the body has become used to the way it feels on anti-depressants, and going off of them can make you feel worse than you felt before you started taking them.

These side effects are a very common reason that people discontinue taking anti-depressants.  While it's important to talk with your doctor about your side effects, it's important to also remember that these side effects are temporary, and that you will feel better after you have been taking anti-depressants for a while.  If you find that you cannot function without anti-depressants, it's important to talk to your doctor about this, as it may be a sign that you are suffering from depression.

prompt: Create a lesson plan in two different levels: in CEFR A1 and A2 on the topic of friendship. Add a rubric.

Friends can be male or female, old or young, and can be of any race or religion.  No matter who our friends are, they are important to us because they encourage us, support us, and help us when we need it.  Our friends can help us learn new things and share our interests and hobbies.  Friends can also help us when we need advice and support.  They will accept us for who we are and will love us no matter what.  Friends usually spend time together, so they know each other well and can share their lives with each other.  Some people are lucky enough to have a best friend who they can trust and confide in.  No matter how close our friends are, we sometimes argue with them because we don’t always agree on the same things.  That’s normal, but it’s important to remember that at the end of the day, our friends will always support us, no matter what!

prompt: cost of fuel for a 14 mile journey in a car with 48mpg, fuel costs 625 pence per gallon and there is heavy traffic for half the journey
answer:
625p x 14 miles = £88 pence
Car with 48mpg will get 24 miles per gallon
1 gallon of fuel = 4.546 litres
24 miles/4.546 litres = 5.304 miles per litre
24 miles ÷ 5.304 = 4.500 miles
24 miles - 4.5 miles = 19.5 miles
19.5miles ÷ 2 = 9.75 miles
2 gallons of fuel ÷ 5.304 litres = 3.712 gallons
£88 divided by 3.712 gallons = 239 pence per gallon

prompt: How does money go from my pocket, through the stock market, and to support the business I've bought stock from?
answer: There are several ways to think about this. The most common way is to think of the stock market as a very big "store" where companies sell their stock. Your money is like a "customer" and when you want to "buy" stock in a company, you are actually giving the company money. Once you have paid for the stock, you are now a "shareholder" in the company and you own a piece of that company. If you want to "sell" the stock, you can simply find another "customer" to buy the stock from you. Once you have found that other "customer", the "store" will give you the money you originally paid for the stock, and you can pocket that money.

prompt: I need to learn English could you help me and make a exercise
answer:
Hello,
To learn English, you will need to study grammar, vocabulary, and practice reading and writing. The first step is to learn the alphabet and the sounds each letter makes. For example a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, i, j, k, l, m, n, o, p, q, r, s, t, u, v, w, x, y, z. Once you know the alphabet, you will need to learn how to pronounce each sound. For instance, the letter a makes the sound /æ/, as in cat, the letter b makes the sound /b/, as in ball, the letter c makes the sound /s/, as in cup, the letter d makes the sound /d/, as in dog, the letter e makes the sound /ɛ/, as in bat, the letter f makes the sound /f/, as in fish, the letter g makes the sound /g/, as in goose, the letter h makes the sound /h/, as in hall, the letter i makes the sound /ɪ/, as in hit, the letter j makes the sound /dʒ/, as in jump, the letter k makes the sound /k/, as in kettle, the letter l makes the sound /l/, as in leg, the letter m makes the sound /m/, as in mouse, the letter n makes the sound /n/, as in knife, the letter o makes the sound /oʊ/, as in gold, the letter p makes the sound /p/, as in pot, the letter q makes the sound /k/, as in queer, the letter r makes the sound /r/, as in rat, the letter s makes the sound /s/, as in see, the letter t makes the sound /t/, as in table, the letter u makes the sound /ʌ/, as in cup, the letter v makes the sound /v/, as in very, the letter w makes the sound /w/, as in witch, the letter x makes the sound /ɪks/, as in mix, the letter y makes the sound /j/, as in yellow, the letter z makes the sound /z/, as in zoo. Once you know how to pronounce each sound, you can begin to learn how the letters combine to form words. There are many resources that can help you learn how to read and write English. Once you can read and write English, you will want to practice by reading and writing English frequently. Reading and writing frequently will help you gain vocabulary and improve your grammar skills.

prompt: Why does warmth make you feel tired?
answer: The cooler your body temperature is, the more your heart pumps blood to warm you up. This is called your body's "fight-or-flight" response, and it increases your heart rate and blood pressure. Your body is working harder to stay at a normal temperature, and that uses up a lot of energy.

prompt: Explain me the Finite Elemente Method
answer: The finite element method is a numerical field for solving problems of engineering and other physical sciences. The basic premise of the method is to divide the problem into smaller sub-problems which can be solved exactly or approximately and then to combine the results of these sub-problems to obtain a solution for the original problem. The smaller problems are called the elements of the model. The method is a meshfree method.

Now, in classical Christian theology, the church has not defined in detail exactly how that inspiration takes place, or what we would call the mode of the inspiration. prompt: Introduce the ”financial markets and institutions“ by Frederic S. Mishkin
answer:
The financial markets and institutions: This is a basic textbook on finance that introduces students to the core topics of financial economics. The book covers the main tools and models of financial economics, including the time-value-of-money, the valuation of bonds and stocks, the risk-return tradeoff, the capital asset pricing model, arbitrage arguments, portfolio theory and the efficient-market hypothesis. The author introduces the material in a clear and intuitive way, while providing a solid foundation for advanced studies in finance.

The book is divided into three parts. Part I introduces and develops the core concepts of finance, including the time-value-of-money, the risk-return tradeoff, the capital asset pricing model, arbitrage arguments, and the efficient-market hypothesis. Part II teaches students how to value bonds, both in theory and in practice, using the techniques learned in the first part of the book. Part III covers the fundamentals of stock valuation, including a discussion of the dividend discount model, the Gordon growth model, and the Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model.

The textbook includes a variety of examples and exercises to assist with the learning process. It also includes a solutions manual.

prompt: what are five important topics for game design
answer:
1) Gameplay: The actions, challenges and the experience of playing the game. The gameplay is the actual experience and interaction with a game.
2) Aesthetics: The visual elements and presentation of the game. The aesthetics of a game includes the graphics, audio, user interface and visual style.
3) Artificial intelligence: The intelligence of non-player characters (NPCs) and the enemy characters in a game. AI is used to create computer controlled characters that opponents in a game.
4) Game world: The setting and environment of the game. The game world of a game includes the geographical location, time, and rules which define the game universe.
5) Game engine: The core software responsible for the rendering and behaviour of the game world. The game engine is the software which manages the game's physics, rendering, and AI.

prompt: 2 / 2can you list in bullet points for the role of digital health in preventing the diseases
answer:
Digital health can play a critical role in preventing diseases by allowing patients to monitor their health in real time, by allowing patients and physicians to communicate and collaborate more effectively, and by helping patients to better understand their own health and the importance of taking steps to manage their health.

When patients are able to monitor their own health in real time, they are more likely to identify issues before they progress to become more serious problems. With access to their own health data, patients are better able to understand what is normal for them and can more easily spot issues that may be cause for concern. 

By allowing patients to communicate and collaborate with their physicians directly and more effectively, digital health can help to improve patient-physician engagement and empower patients to take a more active role in managing their own health. 

By providing patients with more information and data about their own health, digital health can help educate patients about the importance of taking steps to manage their own health and the benefits of adopting healthy habits.

prompt: Act like a first-year college student and write a 1000-1250 word two-topic essay by using at least three points of analysis. Topic 1 is my experiences living in and observations of  Flagstaff, Arizona.   Topic 2 is my experiences living in and observations of  Kaneohe, Hawaii. Use quotes from two sources in the essay. Use descriptive language.  Include personal anecdotes.  These sources will be listed in a Works Cited at the end of the essay. Use a four in-text citations in MLA style in the body of the essay.
answer:
I have lived for the past 21 years in Flagstaff, Arizona, a small city in northern Arizona with a population of around 50,000 people.  Flagstaff is located at an elevation of around 7,000 feet, and is home to the northernmost ski resort in North America.  The city is also home to Northern Arizona University, with over 30,000 students.  Flagstaff is located in the middle of the largest contiguous ponderosa pine forest in the world.  The ponderosa pine forests of northern Arizona are also the headwaters for the Colorado River.  As a result of this unique location, the city has a mild and dry climate with four distinct seasons.  The city also has a very low crime rate.  The population of the city is a diverse mix of young college students, retirees, military veterans, and people from the Native American tribes of the area. 

Although I have lived in Flagstaff for 21 years, I have also lived in other areas of the United States, including the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, and Washington D.C.  Growing up in California, I am used to the mild weather of the coastal areas of the west coast and the dense coniferous forests of the northwest.  I also find the large cities to be more interesting and exciting than the small towns of the midwest and south.  However, as I have grown older, I have come to appreciate small towns and the slower pace of life.  I have also become more interested in the natural world and the outdoors, which is very much a part of life in Flagstaff.  The city is the base for many outdoor activities, including hiking, mountain biking, rock climbing, skiing, and snowboarding.  The beauty of the surrounding landscape, combined with the mild weather, makes Flagstaff a great place to enjoy the outdoors year-round.

answer: Backlinks are when another website links back to your site. For example, when you write a blog post, and another blogger reads it, and links to it in their blog post, that's a backlink. Backlinks are important for SEO for two reasons: 1) it indicates to search engines like Google who your site is and how relevant your site is to that topic. If you have many backlinks, it means other people who read your content also think it's relevant, and Google will rank your site higher. 2) Backlinks are a way for search engines to find new pages on your site. If another website links to a page on your site that doesn't already have a URL, that's called a deep link, and it helps search engines find that page so they can show it in search results.

prompt: is queue an ADT or a data structure
answer: ADT queues are abstract data types that model the concept of a queue. They are usually defined as data structures that store a list of items and allow the insertion or removal of items from the front of the list. The first element inserted becomes the front element of the queue and the last element removed is the back element of the queue. When an element is inserted at the front of the queue, it displaces the front element and becomes the new front element. When an element is removed from the queue, it is removed from the list and the new back element becomes the new front element. Many implementations of queues use linked lists to store the elements and allow insertion and deletion at the front or the back of the list. The complexity of operations on a queue is typically O(1), which makes it a good data structure for implementing various algorithms that require the operations to be performed efficiently.

prompt: 2 / 2Can a qualifying manager work remotely abroad for US employer for an year be eligible for Eb1-C while on h1-b
answer:
To be eligible for the EB-1C, the qualifying manager must have been working for your U.S. employer for at least one year. The year of qualifying work experience must be in a managerial capacity, which is defined as having the authority to hire and fire or supervise other employees. The qualifying manager must also have been employed outside of the U.S. in a managerial position for at least one of the three years prior to filing the EB-1C.

If the qualifying manager is outside of the U.S. and the U.S. employer files an EB-1C petition on behalf of the qualifying manager, the qualifying manager may remain outside of the U.S. until the EB-1C petition is approved and the qualifying manager can return to the U.S. with a valid immigrant visa.

prompt:
question about Computer architecture and organization 
for 6 marks
what in general terms is the distinction between computer organization and computer architecture ?
give answer in full sentence points if possible
answer: The distinction between computer organization and computer architecture is largely one of scope. Computer organization is concerned with the physical implementation of computer systems, including the specification and design of the hardware. Computer architecture, on the other hand, focuses on the design of computer systems at a higher level of abstraction, at or slightly below the level of the instruction set and microarchitecture.

prompt: I am an aikido teacher and student of Tomita Seiji who is living in Belgium. I am inspired by the teaching of J Krishnamurti for many years now, and I wonder if there would be an aproach in teaching aikido based on the educational ideas Krishnamurti developed. Can you suggested some posibilities in a concise way?
answer:
Krishnamurti was a teacher and writer on how to live and how to teach. He was widely regarded as an enlightened being. He questioned the validity of all teachings, including his own. He did not accept the role of a guru, nor did he ask his students to adopt any belief system. His teachings are described as non-sectarian. They are meant to be a radical departure from traditional belief systems of all types, including atheism.

Krishnamurti believed the essential problem was psychological not spiritual. He believed that one must study the self and change it before attempting to transform society. He did not believe in the reformation of society because people are social beings and cannot be expected to transform themselves individually. Krishnamurti explained the process of self-transformation as a "way of being" rather than of doing. He observed that human beings are psychological beings who live in a world of symbols. He believed that the root cause of psychological problems was a person's identification with the symbol, rather than with the underlying reality. He explained that the root cause of the problems in society was that people identify themselves with their emotions, thoughts, and physical sensations, and fail to understand that they are not those things.

Krishnamurti criticized the tendency of conventional schools and societies to condition people to conform, and therefore stifle their ability to think and act spontaneously. He believed that schools and other institutions condition people to accept beliefs that they may not actually hold or may outgrow.

Krishnamurti suggested that the fundamental problem in human psychology is a lack of intelligence, and that this lack is reflected in ignorance, fear, and aggression. He believed that in order to end conflict and violence, it is necessary to understand and transform the human mind.  Krishnamurti proposed that "truth is a pathless land". He argued that one cannot approach truth through study, or accumulate it through memory or intellectual assent. He claimed that truth is a matter of direct experience, and that it is accessible to each person if the mind is quiet and still. He insisted that all psychological and spiritual change must come through the direct action of self observation, without any outside influence or interference.

prompt: Need 300 words on the importance to documenting history in relation to the future
answer:
Documenting history is important in relation to the future in various ways. When you document the history of something, you create a record of what has happened and what took place. This information can be beneficial to people in the future, as it allows them to know about the past and learn from it. 

By documenting the history of something, you also create a record of who was involved, what was achieved, and what challenges were faced. It is good for people in the future to know about this so they can understand what came before them and learn from the experiences and outcomes of past events.

Documenting history can also help to preserve the past for future generations. This can be useful if a particular place or thing is significant or has some cultural or historical value. When you document the history of something, you can help to ensure that the history of the past is not forgotten.

Documenting history can also be important in relation to the future because it can help to shape the future. Sometimes you can learn from the past to help you understand what has worked well in the past and what may work well in the future.

prompt: Why did the building of a pipeline have to be voted on by the government(USA)? Doesn't this infringe on government interfering with private corporations?
answer:
In the United States, interstate pipelines must be approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The FERC determines whether or not a pipeline is in the public interest and whether it is necessary.

The reason that the building of a pipeline has to be voted on by the government is because a pipeline is a huge infrastructure project. It is a major undertaking and can have a big impact on the environment and people's lives. So, the government needs to make sure that it is in the public interest to build such a major infrastructure project and that it will not negatively impact the environment.

answer: Most of the basic functions of current virtualization software are inherited from this early VM OS. The virtualization software is now represented with the term hypervisor. Hardware virtualization is used to share the resources of the cloud providers effectively with the customers by generating an illusion of dedicated computing, storage, and networking on a computing infrastructure. The concept of virtualization is physically implemented using the hypervisor modules, and the operation and processing of hypervisors are materialized by the OSS. In other words, hypervisor modules are installed on top of OSS, which act as an interface between hardware units and hypervisor packages.

prompt: i assume you are familiar with the Drake equation. Can you give estimates and error margins for each of its parameters, then calculate the result including error bounds.
answer: The Drake equation is an equation that estimates the number of advanced civilizations in the Milky Way Galaxy that might be communicating with us at any given moment. The equation contains factors that deal with the creation of stars, the formation of planetary systems, the likelihood of those planetary systems to support life, the likelihood of life to evolve on habitable planets, the likelihood of life to produce intelligent beings, and the likelihood of communicating civilizations to develop technology that allows them to communicate across space. It does not account for the fact that intelligent civilizations may not last long enough to communicate or that they may be unable to communicate because they do not have the technological means.

prompt: what are african governments doing to improve air traffic connectivity
answer:
Air traffic connectivity is a crucial enabler for economic growth. It is responsible for moving people, goods and services across borders, facilitating trade and investment, and improving access to healthcare and education. A lack of air connectivity can hinder development, limiting opportunities for growth, diversification, and job creation.

The African Union Commission has identified air connectivity as a priority area for the continent. Several African governments have taken steps to improve air traffic connectivity on the continent. These include the launch of new airlines and direct flights, improving airport infrastructure and air traffic management systems, and negotiating air service agreements with other countries.

The African Union Commission developed the African Air Traffic Development Plan (AATDP) in 2014. The AATDP is a 15-year blueprint for air traffic development across the continent. The AATDP was developed by the African Civil Aviation Commission, and endorsed by the African Union Assembly of Heads of State and Government in 2014. The plan was updated in 2017, to align with the Sustainable Development Goals. The AATDP aims to:

• increase air traffic flow and connectivity on the continent
• improve safety and enhance the competitiveness of African air transport
• support the development of new airlines and airports
• facilitate tourism, trade and investment
• contribute to the economic development of Africa.

The plan outlines a number of strategic objectives for improving air traffic connectivity. These include:

• developing a regional air traffic network
• improving airport infrastructure
• strengthening air navigation services
• implementing modern technology
• improving air traffic management systems
• developing an aviation human resource base
• building partnerships
• establishing a single African sky
• developing an aviation safety and security system.

The AATDP also contains a number of specific actions to achieve these goals. These include:

• developing and implementing a comprehensive air transport master plan
• establishing a single African sky (SASP)
• establishing an African aviation safety and security oversight body
• establishing an African Aviation Safety and Security Group (AASG)
• establishing a regional aeronautical communication, navigation and surveillance (CNS) system
• establishing an African air traffic management organisation
• signing and implementing air services agreements
• implementing a sustainable financing framework for air traffic management, airports and aviation safety
• implementing the Cape Town Flexible Use Airspace (FUA) concept
• implementing the Single European Sky (SES)
• developing and implementing an airline hub strategy
• establishing an aviation training academy
• developing an aviation security strategy
• establishing a regional airports development fund
• establishing an aeronautical communication, navigation and surveillance (CNS) harmonisation programme
• implementing the ICAO Global Air Navigation Plan (GANP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Airline Security Plan (GASP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Aviation Safety Plan (GASP)
• developing a regional aviation security programme
• implementing the ICAO Global Mega-hub Airport Development Programme
• establishing a regional aviation security organisation
• improving airspace and air traffic management capacity
• implementing a regional airspace usage and capacity management programme
• implementing the ICAO Global Plan of Action to Address Transnational Security Threats to Civil Aviation (GPA)
• implementing the ICAO Global Aviation Security Plan (GASP)
• establishing a global aviation security network
• implementing the ICAO Global Mega-hub Airport Development Programme
• implementing the ICAO Global Aviation Security Plan (GASP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Plan of Action to Address Transnational Security Threats to Civil Aviation (GPA)
• implementing the ICAO Global Aviation Security Plan (GASP)
• establishing regional aviation security organisations
• implementing the ICAO Global Mega-hub Airport Development Programme
• implementing the ICAO Global Air Navigation Plan (GANP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Airline Security Plan (GASP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Air Transport Plan (GATP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Aviation Security Plan (GASP)
• implementing the ICAO Global Civil Aviation Security Plan (GCASP)

prompt: Write a pitch for a horror movie that plays on the island Sylt in northern germany in the 19th century. Include fishermen and a sinister force that drives the inhabitants insane.
answer: A group of fisherman on the island of Sylt in northern germany, find themselves in the middle of a storm.  They make it to shore only to find that there are no other signs of life on the island. Tired and hungry they make their way through the woods to find some shelter.  The next morning they wake to find that the island is completely deserted, with no signs of an animal attack or other cause for the inhabitants to flee.  As they continue to explore the island, they come across a mysterious structure in the middle of the woods.  Intrigued, they venture inside to find out what the structure is.  Once inside they find a large room full of coffins and the smell of decay.  One of the fisherman recognizes the structure as a cemetery from the 19th century.  They leave the cemetery and continue to explore the island, only to find more graves and the remains of an old church.  The fisherman find a journal that belonged to a man named Wilhelm Brandt, who was the last priest on the island.  The journal reveals that the island was plagued with a mysterious illness that drove the inhabitants insane.  The sickness was later believed to be caused by a curse placed on the island by an angry spirit.  The islanders fled the island in the dead of night by boat, leaving the island deserted and their dead behind.

prompt: what are the important points for brand promotion and brand marketing
answer:
Brand marketing is the process of planning and executing strategies that promote a brand and establishes a connection with consumers. Brand promotion is the activity of creating awareness about your brand.

The main goal of brand marketing is to build a relationship between consumers and the brand. Brand marketing is about understanding consumers and using that insight to create a consistent message across all marketing channels.

When it comes to brand marketing, there are three important points to keep in mind:
1. Understanding your target audience. It's essential to understand who your target audience is and what motivates them. Focus on creating a connection with your audience by delivering relevant content.
2. Developing a consistent brand message. Once you understand your target audience, it's important to develop a consistent and recognizable brand message. This includes choosing a logo, color palette and tone of voice that can be used across all marketing channels.
3. Measure the performance of your marketing strategies. Brand marketing isn't about guessing what consumers want — it's about testing your assumptions and measuring the performance of your strategies. This means looking at data to understand which marketing channels are working and which aren't.

prompt: Digital transformation project plan example
answer:
The following document is an example of a high level project plan for a digital transformation project. The project is broken down into five phases:

- PHASE 1: Identify the current state
- PHASE 2: Define the desired state
- PHASE 3: Design the target architecture
- PHASE 4: Build and test the target architecture
- PHASE 5: Migrate to the target architecture

The first phase of the project is to understand the current state of the business and IT systems. This includes documenting the current process and technology stack, identifying business requirements and performing a gap analysis.

The second phase of the project is to define the desired state of the business and IT systems. This includes documenting the target process and technology architecture, and performing a gap analysis to identify the required changes to the current state.

The third phase of the project is to design the target architecture. This involves documenting the target process and technology architecture, and performing a proof of concept to demonstrate that the target architecture is feasible.

The fourth phase of the project is to build and test the target architecture. This involves building and testing the target process and technology architecture, and incorporating any changes identified during the proof of concept into the target architecture.

The fifth and final phase of the project is to migrate to the target architecture. This involves migrating from the current state to the target architecture.

prompt: #2. To increase the energy efficiency of windows, additional glass pane is added. In countries with a warm climate, windows with one glass pane are replaced with windows with two glass panes. Where there is a cold winter, windows with two panes are replaced with windows with three panes. Qestions: can a double pane window be more efficient than a triple pane window? Can a single pane window be more efficient than a double pane window? If yes, what is needed for this? Support your answer with appropriate calculations.
answer: A double pane window can be more efficient than a triple pane window. This is because the additional layer of gas between the panes acts as an insulator, keeping heat in and cold out. However, a triple pane window can be more efficient than a double pane window in cold climates, where the extra layer of glass and gas is desirable to keep heat in. In warmer climates, the opposite is true: the extra glass and gas may make the window less efficient.

prompt: How does Kahane's ethics of violence echo that of Fanon and Zizek when discussing to the American Jewish Establishment?
answer: For Fanon, violence is a "weapon for the oppressed". It is "a tactic of the weak, to counter the violence of the powerful" and is "inevitable" because "violence is immanent in the structure of things". For Fanon, violence is not "good" or "bad". It is a fact of life, a necessity, and a potential solution to the problems of colonialism. Zizek asserts, "violence is a human universal".  He argues that we cannot simply ban violence, nor will a pacifist society be a good one. Zizek uses the example of the pacifist who believes that violence is a mistake and that we should avoid it at all costs. But this pacifist is likely to be exploited by others. Zizek argues that this is the "myth of the good man", and that a truly good man is someone who is strong enough to defend himself, and who does not allow himself to be exploited.

prompt: Make a slide to introduce Cantonese
answer:
Cantonese (Written: 粵語/粵人, Cantonese pronunciation: [kʰɐ́ŋ.tón˨˩˦ sau˨˩]; colloquially: 廣東話/廣東人, Gwan­dung­wa / Gwan­dung­jen, literally "Guangdong speech/Guangdong people") is a variety of Chinese spoken in the province of Guangdong in southeastern China, including the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau, by the people of those regions, and by expatriates from those regions.

Cantonese is considered one of the variety of languages known as Chinese. In Mainland China, it is the lingua franca of the province of Guangdong and is used in the official communications with the province. 

Cantonese is also one of the 5 national dialects in China, the others being the Beijing dialect, the Mandarin dialect, the Shanghainese dialect, and the Wu dialect. 

Cantonese is a branch of the Chinese language, part of the Southwestern branch of Chinese. 

Cantonese is most closely related to Yue Chinese (including Taishanese, Tongyuanese, and Anhai), and the two groups of varieties can be mutually intelligible. Although Cantonese is an independent branch of the Chinese language, it is still influenced by other varieties of Chinese, especially Mandarin, because of the history of contact between Guangdong and the surrounding regions.

The most significant feature which sets Cantonese apart from other varieties of Chinese is the use of an additional tone—the "falling tone"—in certain syllable final positions. This distinction is used in the classification of the various varieties of Chinese to distinguish those varieties that lack this tone, such as Mandarin, from varieties that have it, such as Cantonese and most other Southwestern varieties.

While Cantonese shares much vocabulary with Mandarin, and they are both written with the same characters, Cantonese is not mutually intelligible with Mandarin without prior study. 

Because of its widespread use in broadcast and other media in Hong Kong and Macau, and by the large number of overseas Chinese communities in Southeast Asia, North America, and elsewhere, Cantonese is one of the most-spoken varieties of Chinese in the world.

Write up insights from the book Upstream by Dan Heath and the book’s application to a team of Social Workers at Visalia Unified School District that have the following job description:
Under the direction of an assigned supervisor, the School Social Worker will provide school-based mental health services at school sites. prompt: how are carbon fibers used in buildings
answer: Carbon fibers are used in construction because of their high strength to weight ratio. They can be woven into a fabric, which can then be used to make composites. Composites made from carbon fibers are much stronger than composites made from other materials, and can be lighter weight. Combined with their high strength and low weight, they are used in many high-performance applications, including sports equipment, aircraft, and spacecraft.

prompt: how much of a threat is climate change in the coming years, and what should we do to stop it?
answer:
Climate change is extremely dangerous and we need to take action to stop it. There are four main ways of addressing climate change: 1) reducing emissions of greenhouse gases, 2) removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, 3) adapting to the impacts of climate change that are already unavoidable, and 4) building resilience against future climate impacts.

The most important way of addressing climate change is reducing emissions of greenhouse gases. The next most important way of addressing climate change is removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. These two strategies are known as "mitigation".

We can also adapt to the impacts of climate change that are already unavoidable. And we can build resilience against future climate impacts. Together, these four strategies form a "mitigation and adaptation" approach to addressing climate change.

prompt: Why does it feel like less effort to watch 3 - hour long TV episodes back to back than a film?
answer:
Think about the first time you watched a movie at the theater, then later watched it at home. You probably weren't as engaged by it when you watched it from home, right? 
This is because watching a movie at the theater is an experience. The big screen, the surround sound, the darkness -- all of these elements work together to make watching a movie a unique event. And of course, the movie itself is designed to be experienced in one sitting. There are long takes, with lots of dialogue, and the pacing is different than a TV show.

On the other hand, a TV show is designed to be consumed in bite-size pieces. The episodes are usually shorter, and there's a lot of action and dialogue crammed into each one. The story is usually more serialized, and the pace is definitely faster.

So you could argue that the reason it feels like less effort to watch a TV show back to back is because the experience is more satisfying. It's like going to a well-cooked meal versus eating a bowl of cold cereal. You get more enjoyment out of the former, and it takes more effort.

prompt: Explain sarcoidosis to me like I’m a five year old
answer: Sarcoidosis is a disease that causes small clumps of inflammatory cells to form in the body's tissues. The inflammation triggered by these clumps can damage the tissue in the affected area, and in rare cases might spread to other parts of the body. The inflammation can cause a variety of symptoms and signs, such as coughing, shortness of breath, fatigue, and loss of appetite.

prompt: write a chronology of important events related to ESG in 2022
answer:
2022 will be remembered as a historic year for ESG.
In January, a new US President took office and vowed to end the government's war on coal, which was one of the most important policy changes for the US power sector.
In early February, after months of speculation, the US Federal Reserve announced that it would be cutting interest rates for the first time since the 2008 financial crisis.
In March, oil prices hit 3-year highs, with Brent crude oil trading above US$70 per barrel for the first time in 4 years.
These two policy changes, coupled with the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in March, prompted many companies to rethink their plans for 2022 and beyond.

In May, the European Union (EU) and Japan agreed to a free trade agreement (FTA) with the US, which was seen as a major win for US President Donald Trump.
Earlier in the year, the EU and Japan had already announced their intention to conclude an FTA with Canada.
Together, these three agreements could usher in a new era of global trade.

In June, the European Commission proposed revisions to the EU's carbon pricing system, including a new mechanism for pricing carbon emissions from flights.

In July, the US House of Representatives passed a bill that would enact major reforms to the US electricity system, including the phase-out of coal-fired power plants and a transition to renewable energy.

In August, the UK government introduced a new plan that would see a 60% cut in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2030, compared to 1990 levels.

In September, the International Energy Agency (IEA) published its annual World Energy Outlook, which projected that the world would miss its 2020 carbon emissions target by a wide margin.

In October, the COP26 climate summit was held in Glasgow, Scotland from 9 to 23 November 2021.
The summit was the year's most important climate conference, and was seen as a crucial test for the UK government as it tries to host a successful summit after the failure of COP25 in 2019.

prompt: Write a list of measures and ideas how  the Sophia Jewish can foster more Shabbat celebration and observance at home and in synagogue
answer:
1. Have a Shabbat Kiddush every Shabbat in the main sanctuary. This is a great way to welcome the community and provide new families with the opportunity to meet other members of the community.
2. Have a Shabbat dinner every Shabbat in the Social Hall. This gives people who are unable to host their own Shabbat dinner a chance to come together with friends and family.
3. Provide educational materials for families to help them learn more about Shabbat observance. This could include a guide with family-friendly ideas for Shabbat activities and a suggested menu for Shabbat dinner.
4. Provide prayer booklets that families can use to lead their own Shabbat services at home.
5. Host a Shabbat program for children at the synagogue. This will give children the opportunity to be part of a Shabbat service, but in a way that is more age-appropriate than the main sanctuary service.
6. Host a Shabbat program for families with young children. This would include a Shabbat service, followed by a light snack, and then an activity for the children.
7. Have a Shabbat trivia night. This is a fun event that could be held at the synagogue or at a local restaurant.
8. Have a Shabbat market where members of the community bring homemade or homegrown items to sell. This could be held at the synagogue or at a local venue.

prompt: 7 / 7Write a detailed patent writing for an innovative and novel way of issuing community tax certificates and other relevant permits and clearances as a digital certificates,  that is non-obvious using verifiable credentials, digital wallet on a blockchain as payment provision, and machine learning. Include claims on detailed processes involved, system architecture and algorithms
answer:
The innovation proposed here is to issue community tax certificates and other relevant permits and clearances as digital certificates on a blockchain. It leverages verifiable credentials, digital wallet on a blockchain as payment provision, and machine learning.

This innovation provides a digital certificate for tax compliance on a blockchain. The digital certificate can be used to generate a digital signature, which can be used to authenticate the holder of the certificate. The digital signature can be verified using verifiable credentials. The digital certificate can be used to authenticate a user for access to the government services/systems.

Further, the digital certificate can be used to generate a QR code, which can be used to generate a digital receipt. The digital receipt can be used to generate a transaction on a blockchain. The digital receipt can be verified using digital signatures. Further, the digital receipt can be used to generate a QR code, which can be used to verify the authenticity of the receipt.

The digital certificate can be issued using verifiable credentials, digital wallet on a blockchain as payment provision, and machine learning. Further, the digital receipt and the digital certificate can be verified using verifiable credentials, digital wallet on a blockchain as payment provision, and machine learning.

prompt:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "There’s much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where we’re from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us ‘us,’ we’ve got a lot to say.
While you don’t need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where ‘foundered’ sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more ‘clinker’ than ‘beezer’? Or appreciating that ‘grand’ can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
“I think it’s really important,” says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
“I think sometimes we’re not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
“Often the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,” he continues.
“Slang as a sort of term that’s used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
“We have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language that’s used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but they’re really quite amazing things.”
“It’s a potentially massive term,” says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
“One of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
“But then you’ve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; he’s been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
“It’s a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.”
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that we’re all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
“It’s one of those things that if we go on holiday and you’re walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like ‘yer ma’, or ‘yer man’ and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings don’t and can’t,” says Dr Ferguson.
“There’s something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and there’s nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
“Sometimes we might get anxious that we’re using cliches, but we’re actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.”
Think too of Line of Duty’s Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didn’t come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGee’s Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
“That really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
“Sometimes we’ve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.”
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
“I think it’s unfortunate that it’s been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,” says Gail.
“It’s so frustrating but I think there’s definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
“And it’s such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. It’s one dimension of what slang can do.”
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
“In many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
“We have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
“We are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for ‘potatoes’ that we have.
“Certain areas will have a certain word for certain things and that’s a real strength. I think there’s a variety there and there’s a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I don’t think we’ve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.”
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a ‘boak’ after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done ‘the messages’? My favourite slang word ‘hoke’ has an Ulster Scots origin. It’s fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
“Often there’s not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that it’s bad language, or it doesn’t have a sense of value behind it,” says Dr Ferguson.
“But on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
“There are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when it’s authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and you’re in the room.
“Whenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burns’ To a Mouse and ‘wee, sleekit, cowrin, tim’rous beastie’ appears in the first line.
“This really electrifies him because the word ‘wee’ appears. It’s the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and it’s also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
“I think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think we’ve grown up with, we’re maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, there’s something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that don’t connect us.”
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is we’re trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Ireland’s case, that we have multiple uses for the word ‘wee.’
“We all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when it’s Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know we’re foundered,” says Dr Ferguson.
“One of our great words, and I think there’s a difference between the town and city where it’s ‘scunnered’ or ‘scundered’. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of ‘I am totally scunnered’ or ‘I am totally scundered’ about something. These are things that we should protect.”
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
“Yesterday’s slang term is today or the future’s commonly understood term for something,” she explains.
“I guess that’s how language changes and evolves, through its users. You’re getting a people’s history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
“Every year I’m always interested to see what makes it into the OED — it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
“In 2022, ‘a chara’ entered the OED. So did ‘fluthered’, first used by James Joyce in 1927, ‘gaslighter’ and ‘vaxxed’. It’s great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what we’re living through.”
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the ‘beauty’ of slang is that it’s often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
“It often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,” he laughs.
“But there’s a there’s a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. They’re used in some circles and in some groups.
“We all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that we’ve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, ‘uni’ seems one of the obvious words to use because it’s been floating through media, but it’s loaded into everyday speech.
“Language is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that we’re not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.”
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, they’re widely available for visitors to enjoy — on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
“I think it’s actually gotten more popular,” she says of the slang-adorned items.
“There’s more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
“I think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.”
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where we’re proud of the places we call home.
From ‘up to high doh’ coasters to ‘a wee bag’ tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
“I knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast — 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,” explains Linzi.
“With the Americans coming over and they ask, ‘What’s “awk hiya love?”’ – which we have on our socks and mugs – once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So they’re running around America with a pair of ‘awk hiya love’ socks on with people asking, ‘What’s awk?’
“It creates engagement in the shop and it’s probably why the shop is doing so well as it’s creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
“It opens conversations which is brilliant.”
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with ‘alright big lad’ and customers still love ‘Ulster says yeooo!’ and ‘ats us nai’.
“Having tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,” continues Linzi.
“For the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
There’s no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.”
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
“I was always very conscious that it’s how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and it’s a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, it’s quite popular.
“It may not want to be a mug you’d have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their ‘alright’ sock in a style that’s trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If you’re able to tie those two together then you’ve got a good product. It’s not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.”
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
“I’m married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,” says Gail. “Simple things like I’ll say ‘plaster’ and she’ll say ‘Band-aid,’ I’ll say ‘chips’ and she’ll say ‘fries’. He knows that he’s betwixt and between terms.
“Even things like ‘wee’ and ‘what’s the craic?’ There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone who’s not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, ‘Well, hello, what’s the craic?’ Or even words like ‘scundered’ or ‘jammy,’ or ‘dead on,’ all these things that I say quite often.”"

prompt: How can I calculate the amount of variations on a 3x4 table?
